field_edited_text.value:
o -

SUMMARY

Anticipated traffic increases constitute one of the principal justifi-
cations for construction of an East-West Expressway through the
City. Present estimates indicate that east-west traffic will increase
by approximately 509 by 1980. Since existing east-west streets are
now operating at about capacity all of the anticipated increase should
be handled by new routes or by widenings of existing streets.

An East-West Expressway eight lanes wide would take care of 40%
to 509% of expected traffic increases over the next twenty years.
Together with other needed improvements the East-West Expressway
should absorb the increase in east-west traffic anticipated by 1980
and in addition provide some measure of relief to present traffic con-
gestion. This relief would be most pronounced during non-rush hours.

The need for an East-West Expressway is based upon local traffic and
not through traffic. East-West Expressway traffic having neither
origin nor destination within the metropolitan area is estimated to be
no more than 69 of total traffic on the expressway.

While an improved public transportation system is urgently needed,
the best feasible system would not noticeably affect the need for an
East-West Expressway.

The need for a major cross-town expressway has long been recog-
nized. Eight major proposals for such an expressway have been made
between 1942 and 1957. All of these proposals are based upon an
alignment crossing the center of the City just north of the central
business district. The last of these eight proposals was included as
part of the Planning Commission’s 1957 expressway plan. It is
referred to in this report as the Northern Route to distinguish it
from other proposed East-West Expressway alignments.

Since the first expressway proposal in 1942, all plans and studies for



handling anticipated traffic increases have placed major reliance upon
a highway system involving one or more expressways having complete
access control and complete grade separation from conflicting traffic.
Expressways have distinct advantages over other types of highways.
They are safer and they save travel time. They are inherently free
from encroachment from abutting properties and their capacity thus

endures. Expressways can serve to reduce blight and to facilitate
urban renewal through removing traffic (including truck traffic) from -

residential streets. (Other advantages and characteristics of express-
ways are di{scqssed in the body of the report.)

. While expressways have distinct advantages over other types of high-

ways they also have drawbacks and if improperly located or designed
they can act as a blighting influence on adjacent properties.

The additional traffic capacity which would result from construction
of an East-West Expressway could theoretically also be provided
through widening of existing streets. To do so, however, would
require the removal of approximately two and one-half times as many
buildings as would be razed by the East-West Expressway. The
number of families to be relocated, the loss in taxes, and the cost of
site acquisition would be in proportion. Total cost to the City would
be substantially greater.

. The health of the central business district is based primarily upon its

relative accessibility to all parts of the metropolitan area. This
relative accessibility is enhanced by an expressway system focused on
the central business district; it is diminished by the construction of
expressways not located so as to serve the central business district.
In these terms it will take at least four radial expressways leading
outwards from the center of the City to restore to the central busi-
ness district the loss in relative accessibility which will result from
